node.text:
Statistically we (law enforcement) have a higher probability of a lethal engagement in and or around a vehicle than any other environment.  The national average is currently at 60% with state or traffic driven agencies usually in the 70-80%. Current UCR data shows that 83% of all officer who are killed in the line of duty while conducting self initiated activity, die in or around vehicles.  A study released in 2016 showed 37% of all officers ambushed (while not responding to a call were ambushed, seated inside of their vehicle). That being said know how to fight in and around vehicles.  Don't be the guy trying figure it out for the first time when it's for all the marbles. 

After studying thousands of stateside, LE vehicle based gunfights and establishing scores of federal, state and local LE vehicle based programs (VCQB®️), here are some consistent trends as they relate to this video. 

3.  Movement must be athletic in motion, safe in environment and tactical in decision.  Always look to improve your position through movement but realize that improvement may simply be to a better position on the vehicle.  I hear folks often say "get off the X" and while that is ideal in some cases, most of the time it is not feasible for vehicle based LE engagements. Know how to do both.  When you are in uniform, you are the X... know how to problem solve it if moving away is not readily available. 

4.  Be able to safely drive the gun within close proximity to others.  A common theme with vehicle based engagements  is the presence of a restricted work space.  Know what that looks like and the pros and cons to all muzzle orientations.  The gun can go up, out or down and the environment dictates that direction. 

5.  High ground wins fights... that being said, know how to work from the ground.  The data shows a large number of dudes end up on the ground via slipping, falling, being shot, run over etc.  Don't church up your positional work i.e. you're either fighting from you side, you back or your stomach.  Know how to do it all and don't end up there unless fate demands it of you. 

#centrifugetraining #vcqb®️ #datadriven #lawenforcement #police #tactics #evolve

node.text:
Injured shooter with carbine definitely falls into that low frequency / high consequence realm. 

Transitioning is dependent on several factors like, do I have a handgun to transition to?  Do I have ammo for that secondary?  Is the threat beyond my ability to hit it with a handgun etc etc. 

You’ll need time, distance and cover to work on the patrol rifle.  Using something (in this video a vehicle) to stabilize the long gun is extremely helpful. 

Locking the bolt to the rear is often problematic for students so here’s are few tips to help. 

If you dig this give @centrifugetraining a follow and take a look at our injured shooter courses (we have several coming up). 

Rifle by @triarcsystems 
Clothes by @mantle_clothing 

@oakleystandardissue 
@velocitysystems 
@modlitesystems 

#centrifugetraining #triarcsystems #problemsolving #injuredshooter #oakleystandardissue #modlightsystems #mantleclothing #velocitysystems #context

node.text:
#Repost @nardoctor
・・・
Active shootings have had a recent surge in the US. Here is  a look at historical data from ALERRT (Advanced Law Enforcement Rapid Response Training). The ALERRT Center at Texas State University was created in 2002 as a partnership between Texas State University, the San Marcos, Texas Police Department and the Hays County, Texas Sheriff’s Office to address the need for active shooter response training for first responders. In 2013, ALERRT at Texas State was named the National Standard in Active Shooter Response Training by the FBI.
.
Active Attack Data (2000-2019). Includes gun, knife, vehicle or any means where primary concern is attempt at mass murder. Over half the time there was no relationship of the attacker to the victims. About half the time the attack was over prior to police arrival (21% suicide, 12% fleeing the scene, 16% victims stopped the attacker). 
.
Yearly numbers: Increase in events over the last 5 years. Note, data is still being compiled from 2020 and should be released soon. Events appear to be leveling off at 22/year. 91% firearm followed by knife and car.
.
Location: 47% of attacks occurred at businesses, followed by public areas, schools and then churches. 2 events were happened on military bases. 67% of the events occurred during the day between 7am and 4pm.
.
Number of victims: 1,016 deaths and 1,799 wounded. Most common was 2-4 victims. If the event had a death, about half the time 3 or more were killed. 
.
While you need to be prepared for anything at any time, looking at historical data can be a great place to start when preparing and equipping yourself. Evaluate places you go/live/work and use some creativity on how and when an attack may occur in your area so you can best be prepared to respond. 

#tecc #savinglives #activeshooter #northamericanrescue

node.text:
While fighting from inside a vehicle is far from ideal it is, contextually relevant.

Currently, 37% of LE not responding to calls for service are being ambushed while inside a vehicle with the average distance of 16 feet and in. 

This environment poses many unique obstacles and must be understood and trained to mitigate loss of life. 

Simply telling guys to get out of the vehicle, drive away or figure it out is a less than ideal way of problem solving. 

Modern law enforcement trends need modern law enforcement (data driven) solutions. 

#centrifugetraining #lawenforcement #forcopsbycops #datadriven #vcqb®️ #contextmatters #problemsolving

node.title: Topic: fighting from inside a vehicle.

node.text:
Our friend @costa_ludus talks about... possibly the most important piece of attire... hats. 
・・・
His classes can be found at, www.Costaludus.com.  Attend one, you’ll have a blast a learn a ton.

node.text: The amount of work @chimeraxr has put into ensuring every detail of vehicle based work is accurate is staggering.  Give them a follow... hit their YouTube up and grab a unit when they drop.  #centrifugetraining #chimeraxr #vr #virtualreality #evolve #thefutureisnow #lawenforcement #train #vcqb®️

node.text:
A repost from several years ago...

This falls into the low frequency, high consequence arena but is something that has come up several times.  Running a handgun injured from inside a vehicle.  To put this into context, the several times I have come across the subject an officer that was trapped inside the vehicle. Doors wouldn’t open due to some collision that took place during the pursuit or at the termination of the pursuit and now is faced with a lethal threat from the fleeing offender.  Food for thought... manipulate your environment and use what is readily presented. @agencyarms @velocitysystems @oakleystandardissue #centrifugetraining #agencyarms #context #vcqb®️ #lawenforcement #police #youaretheX #problemsolving #injuredshooter #evolve

node.text: NLTA Performance on Demand (offender firing blanks with Officers utilizing @ultimatetrainingmunitions marking rounds). Students navigate a parking lot environment, occupied vehicles, mobile offender and a downed officer.  Neutralize the threat, work the medial problem and extraction if needed.  #centrifugetraining #lawenforcement #vcqb #performanceondemand #letsseewhatyougot #datadriven #contextual #officerdown #train #evolve #medshit #livesaving #heroshit #problemsolving #problemsolvethex #ultimatetrainingmunitions #bulletsbeforebandaids

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Centrifuge Training on August 18, 2021 tagging @centrifuge_bryan, @ttpoa, and @mantle_clothing. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text: Instructor bio: Bryan (our diversity hire) Veliz @centrifuge_bryan.  Bryan is the newest addition to Centrifuge with 10 years in LE and, like all of our instructors… still actively on the job.  He’s worked patrol, swat and as an in-service instructor for his department on the border.  An extremely effective communicator, who’s passionate about the students, material and telenovelas.  No he’s not 12 that’s just his extensive skin care regimen and exfoliation program you’re picking up on.  He’s the future of progressive LE training. We understand the gravity of that statement, and stand by it.  An experienced @ttpoa instructor he brings a lot to the range.  As a brand new dad, like his baby… he’s tired. A lot.  Give me a 🌮 if you’ve been on the range with our amigo.  #centrifugetraining #datadriven #lawenforcement #swat #patrol #forcopsbycops #bordertown

node.text: Instructor bio: Dan (@danno1812) is still doing the full time LE thing with 14 years on.  He’s currently the ATL for his SWAT team and spent 7 as a k9 handler.  He’s kinda got this lumpy Charlie Brown bald head thing going on but we still love him.  He’s a master class RDS shooter and one of the better material creationists we’ve seen of late.  His favorite past times include: eating bread and spending time with his family.  He’s been responsible for establishing handgun RDS and other instructor level programs at major agencies and is one of our favorite humans.  Give him a follow. Hit me with a 🔴 if you’ve been to one of his RDS classes.  #centrifugetraining #rds #dotlife #swat #train #evolve #lawenforcement #forcopsbycops

node.text: I’m proud of the team we’ve built.  I also think because we as a company preach “data driven”, some interpret that as we don’t have any experience.  In light of that, I wanted to highlight the team, starting with uncle @centrifuge_chase.  First off, he’s old.  You name it in LE he’s done it. With 30 years on (retiring as Captain) if there was a special unit or instructional capacity… he’s done it.  Married to the game, after he retired he got on with another major Sheriff’s Department where he’s assigned to the training division.  He’s full of wisdom, solid TTPs, ill timed jokes and even though he’s in his 50’s he’s putting the young guys to shame on the PT front.  You’ll be hard pressed to find a man with a fancier mobile home (Chase is from Alabama) or better human being.  If you’re not following @centrifuge_chase give him a follow.  If you’ve had the opportunity to share a range with him give me a 🤘. #centrifugetraining #lawenforcement #police #sheriff #datadriven #oldschool #swat #triarcsystems #velocitysystems #oakelystandardissue

node.text:
Part 3 of 3 

Statistically we (law enforcement) have a higher probability of a lethal engagement in and or around a vehicle than any other environment.  The national average is currently at 60% with state or traffic driven agencies usually in the 70-80%. Current UCR data shows that 83% of all officer who are killed in the line of duty while conducting self initiated activity, die in or around vehicles.  A study released in 2016 showed 37% of all officers ambushed (while not responding to a call were ambushed, seated inside of their vehicle). That being said know how to fight in and around vehicles.  Don't be the guy trying figure it out for the first time when it's for all the marbles. 

6.  Use the car.  Regardless of what you believe about what vehicles will or will not stop from a ballistic standpoint... put as much of that mass immediately between you and the threat possible.  Barricades, and in this specific instance the vehicle buys us time.  What you do with that time will depend on your situation. 

7. Port.  No not the kind you drink the kind you make with your gun.  Glass, seats, doors etc etc will deviate and soak up more rounds that you'd expect them too.  Make a hole  and continue to work that port until the desired results are produced.

8.  Be able to run the gun injured.  Due to the often very close proximity of these engagements we find officers get tagged on a pretty regular basis. 

9.  If you have the ability to create holes you should have the ability (both the skill set and kit) to fix them.  Also... be able to conduct your med work injured.  Look to companies for training and well laid out on person Med kits. 

10.  Train.  You can read all the posts, magazine articles, watch all the youtube videos etc you want.  And while that is a start it does not substitute quality training.  Ensure your training is tailored to the environment and job you will be forced to problem solve. 

#centrifugetraining #vcqb®️ #datadriven #lawenforcement #police #context #tactics #problemsolving #trooper #sheriff #deputy

node.text:
Statistically we (law enforcement) have a higher probability of a lethal engagement in and or around a vehicle than any other environment.  The national average is currently at 60% with state or traffic driven agencies usually in the 70-80%. Current UCR data shows that 83% of all officer who are killed in the line of duty while conducting self initiated activity, die in or around vehicles.  A study released in 2016 showed 37% of all officers ambushed (while not responding to a call were ambushed, seated inside of their vehicle). That being said know how to fight in and around vehicles.  Don't be the guy trying figure it out for the first time when it's for all the marbles. 

After studying thousands of stateside, LE vehicle based gunfights and establishing scores of federal, state and local LE vehicle based programs (VCQB®️), here are some consistent trends as they relate to this video. 

3.  Movement must be athletic in motion, safe in environment and tactical in decision.  Always look to improve your position through movement but realize that improvement may simply be to a better position on the vehicle.  I hear folks often say "get off the X" and while that is ideal in some cases, most of the time it is not feasible for vehicle based LE engagements. Know how to do both.  When you are in uniform, you are the X... know how to problem solve it if moving away is not readily available. 

4.  Be able to safely drive the gun within close proximity to others.  A common theme with vehicle based engagements  is the presence of a restricted work space.  Know what that looks like and the pros and cons to all muzzle orientations.  The gun can go up, out or down and the environment dictates that direction. 

5.  High ground wins fights... that being said, know how to work from the ground.  The data shows a large number of dudes end up on the ground via slipping, falling, being shot, run over etc.  Don't church up your positional work i.e. you're either fighting from you side, you back or your stomach.  Know how to do it all and don't end up there unless fate demands it of you. 

#centrifugetraining #vcqb®️ #datadriven #lawenforcement #police #tactics #evolve

node.text:
Part 1 of 3 

Statistically we (law enforcement) have a higher probability of a lethal engagement in and or around a vehicle than any other environment.  The national average is currently at 60% with state or traffic driven agencies usually in the 70-80%. Current UCR data shows that 83% of all officer who are killed in the line of duty while conducting self initiated activity, die in or around vehicles.  A study released in 2016 showed 37% of all officers ambushed (while not responding to a call were ambushed, seated inside of their vehicle). That being said know how to fight in and around vehicles.  Don't be the guy trying figure it out for the first time when it's for all the marbles. 

After studying thousands of stateside, LE vehicle based gunfights and establishing scores of federal, state and local LE vehicle based programs (VCQB®️), here are some consistent trends as they relate to this video. 

1.  It's about the gun not the vehicle.  We say this at the start of every class.  Hits make the bad guy go away and the longer the engagement takes, statistically you (or the people you care about) have a higher probability of being mortally wounded. 

2. This engagement (like most vehicle based engagements) was high intensity, short duration and close proximity.  Ensure your positional work is efficient, data driven and works in close proximity.  Thanks to @effective.fitnesstraining for filming our dueling drill and pairing it with an OIS to show correlation. 
#centrifugetraining #datadriven #vcqb®️ #train #evolve #context #lawenforcement #police #sheriff #trooper #tactics #ballistics.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Centrifuge Training in RCMP Pacific Region Training Centre with @chimeraxr. May be an image of one or more people and people standing.

node.text:
Proud of @chimeraxr and to be their US partner for LE. 
・・・
We are proud that the RCMP chose the ChimeraXR Mythos VR training system as their first VR based firearms and tactics simulator. They are the first national law enforcement agency to adopt a VR solution for training with firearms in a deployable form factor.
.
.
We just wrapped up the end user course to qualify these national instructors on the use of our system for both in person and remote training. We think it's time for LE/Mil agencies to get the benefits of technology and support members with solutions purpose-built for their challenges.
.
.
Absolutely thrilled at this first step towards what may be a nation-wide implementation in the future, taken by these forward thinking instructors. True professionals. 
.
.
Thanks as always to our partners:
@centrifugetraining
@centrifuge_canada
@pekititactics 
@tirsiatraining 
@funkerofficial 
@temple_indexing_mofo 
@launchwcatapult 
BMU Montréal 
.
.
More to follow! #centrifugetraining simulation #training 
#vr #vcqb®️ #lawenforcement #military #augmentedreality #mixedreality
